abstract.text: Receive controller input using either polling or callbacks.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The Game Controller framework provides your game with low-level and fast access to input from connected gamepads, arcade sticks, and racing wheels. Not all games receive and process input the same way. The Game Controller framework input APIs support several ways for your game to receive controller input:

Use polling when input handling occurs at a fixed interval as part of your game’s loop. You request the latest input state from the Game Controller framework each time you handle input. This can occur once per frame, or at a lower frequency than the frame rate.
Use callbacks when the input handling in your game is event-driven. You provide one or more blocks that the Game Controller framework invokes when any or certain elements’ input values change.
You get game controller input from the device’s input profile. The
protocol declares the common properties for the input profile. The
classes provide the concrete implementations for gamepads and arcade sticks, and racing wheels, respectively.

inlineContent.text: The Game Controller framework processes input events, and invokes any configured callbacks, on the

Game controllers organize their input states by elements. These elements correspond to the individual buttons, directional pads, thumbsticks, and other kinds of controls on the gamepad, arcade stick, or racing wheel. Game controllers identify elements by their semantic name, and group them into one or more collections, such as the
To get objects representing specific elements of a controller, use the subscript notation with the collection properties from an object conforming to the

inlineContent.text: Reading a single input value is an atomic operation. However, the current input state can change between reading distinct input values. To avoid these inconsistencies, use the

method to obtain a snapshot of the input state at the current moment. Then read the input values from the snapshot. Snapshots carry very little performance overhead as long as your game doesn’t hold onto the snapshot for long periods of time.

code: // Capture the current controller input state.
// Read the current A and B button pressed states from the snapshot.

inlineContent.text: Sometimes an input device generates input more frequently than your game can process it. For example, a racing wheel with a high refresh rate generates hundreds of inputs per second. If you read the current input values every frame (at 60 frames per second), you miss input events. In this case, configure the Game Controller framework to maintain a queue of input states that you retrieve and process later.

First, change the input queue depth to a value that’s appropriate for the frequency at which your game polls for input. The input queue depth specifies the maximum number of input states that the Game Controller framework buffers before it purges older input states from the queue. The default value of
In your game loop, handle all the inputs that occur after the last iteration of your game loop using the
method until the queue is empty.
Optionally, assign a callback to the
objects. The Game Controller framework calls this block when a new input state becomes available, and not again until your game processes all input states in the queue.

To receive callbacks from specific elements when their inputs change, assign a callback to one or more of the element’s inputs. Then implement the handlers to take the appropriate action for your game.
For example, a button element has a pressed input representing its pressed state. Assign a block to the
property to take an action when the user presses it.

code: // Register a callback for the press/release of the A button.
// Handle when the user presses the button.
// Handle when the user releases the button.

inlineContent.text: To receive a callback when the inputs of any element change, assign a callback to the

objects. When input occurs, the Game Controller framework calls the block once for each element that changes. Your code reads the latest values from the element that Game Controller passes to the handler.

abstract.text: The types of game controller profiles that the app supports or requires.
A Boolean value indicating whether the app supports a game controller.
A Boolean value indicating whether the physical Apple TV Remote and the Apple TV Remote app operate as separate game controllers.
Learn about important changes to Game Controller.
Support hardware game controllers in your game.
The input object that provides the linear and press state of the element.
A representation of a real game controller, a virtual controller, or a snapshot of a controller.
The input profile for the controller.
The input profile for a controller.
The dispatch queue that the framework uses to call element value change handlers.
The common properties and methods for objects that represent the input profile of a device.
Returns a snapshot of the physical device inputs.
A block that the profile calls when an element’s value changes.
The block that the profile calls when Game Controller adds an input state to the queue.
Returns the next input state from the queue.
The dispatch queue that the system uses for callbacks.
It’s unknown whether there’s a change to the input value.
The common properties for physical devices with elements.
Returns whether the input value of an element changes.
Returns the elements that changed since the previous input state.
The block that the profile calls when an element’s press state changes.
An object that represents a physical racing wheel controller connected to a device.
The physical input profile for the racing wheel.
A controller profile that supports a racing wheel.
Receive controller input in the way that best integrates with the flow of your game or game engine.
